The best time to see the new tomistoma is at night at our Snore&Roar overnights http://t.co/PeXmajqh4U. Another good time is late afternoon.
The tomistoma or false gharial is a new species at the Zoo. She lives behind the Reptile Discovery Center next to the Komodo dragon exhibit.
Tomistomas lay eggs in nest mounts in clutches of 13 to 35 eggs. They appear to lay the largest eggs of any living crocodilians.
There aren't many breeding tomistomas in zoos. When ours matures in a few years, she will be an important part of the breeding program.
Tomistomas are critically endangered. There are only ~2,500 adult animals left in the wild in Malaysia, Sarawak, Sumatra & Borneo.
The Zoo has a new resident! A female 16-year-old 7-foot-long false gharial or tomistoma. http://t.co/tU5Dqi7u7g
